column2: CHAPTER XXVI.
column3: CHAPTER twenty six.

column2: WHAT HAPPENED IN THE BACK PARLOUR OF THE BANKING-HOUSE.
column3: WHAT HAPPENED IN THE BACK PARLOUR OF THE BANKING HOUSE.

column2: Henry Dunbar arrived in London a couple of hours after Mr. Vernon left the Abbey.
column3: Henry Dunbar arrived in London a couple of hours after mr Vernon left the Abbey.

column2: He went straight to the Clarendon Hotel.
column3: He went straight to the Clarendon Hotel.

column2: He had no servant with him, and his luggage consisted only of a portmanteau, a dressing-case, and a despatch-box; the same despatch-box whose contents he had so carefully studied at the Winchester hotel, upon the night of the murder in the grove.
column3: He had no servant with him, and his luggage consisted only of a portmanteau, a dressing case, and a despatch box; the same despatch box whose contents he had so carefully studied at the Winchester hotel, upon the night of the murder in the grove.

column2: The day after his arrival was Sunday, and all that day the banker occupied himself in reading a morocco-bound manuscript volume, which he took from the despatch-box.
column3: The day after his arrival was Sunday, and all that day the banker occupied himself in reading a morocco bound manuscript volume, which he took from the despatch box.

column2: There was a black fog upon this November day, and the atmosphere out of doors was cold and bleak.
column3: There was a black fog upon this November day, and the atmosphere out of doors was cold and bleak.

column2: But the room in which Henry Dunbar sat looked the very picture of comfort and elegance.
column3: But the room in which Henry Dunbar sat looked the very picture of comfort and elegance.

column2: He had drawn his chair close to the fire, and on a table near his elbow were arranged the open despatch-box, a tall crystal jug of Burgundy, with a goblet-shaped glass, on a salver, and a case of cigars.
column3: He had drawn his chair close to the fire, and on a table near his elbow were arranged the open despatch box, a tall crystal jug of Burgundy, with a goblet shaped glass, on a salver, and a case of cigars.

column2: Until long after dark that evening, Henry Dunbar sat by the fire, smoking and drinking, and reading the manuscript volume.
column3: Until long after dark that evening, Henry Dunbar sat by the fire, smoking and drinking, and reading the manuscript volume.

column2: He only paused now and then to take pencil-notes of its contents in a little memorandum-book, which he carried in the breast-pocket of his coat.
column3: He only paused now and then to take pencil notes of its contents in a little memorandum book, which he carried in the breast pocket of his coat.

column2: It was not till seven o'clock, when the liveried servant who waited upon him came to inform him that his dinner was served in an adjoining chamber, that Mr. Dunbar rose from his seat and put away the book in the despatch-box.
column3: It was not till seven o'clock, when the liveried servant who waited upon him came to inform him that his dinner was served in an adjoining chamber, that mr Dunbar rose from his seat and put away the book in the despatch box.

column2: He laid down the volume on the table while he replaced other papers in the box, and it fell open at the first page.
column3: He laid down the volume on the table while he replaced other papers in the box, and it fell open at the first page.

column2: On that first page was written, in Henry Dunbar's bold, legible hand--

column2: _Journal of my life in India, from my arrival in 1815 until my departure in 1850._

column2: This was the book the banker had been studying all that winter's day.
column3: This was the book the banker had been studying all that winter's day.

column2: At twelve o'clock the next day he ordered a brougham, and was driven to the banking-house in St. Gundolph Lane.
column3: At twelve o'clock the next day he ordered a brougham, and was driven to the banking house in st Gundolph Lane.

column2: This was the first time that Henry Dunbar had visited the house in St. Gundolph Lane since his return from India.
column3: This was the first time that Henry Dunbar had visited the house in st Gundolph Lane since his return from India.

column2: Those who knew the history of the present chief partner of the house of Dunbar, Dunbar, and Balderby, were in nowise astonished by this fact. They knew that, as a young man, Henry Dunbar had contracted the tastes and habits of an aristocrat, and that, if he had afterwards developed into a clever and successful man of business, it was only by reason of the force of circumstances, which had thrust him into a position that he hated.
column3: Those who knew the history of the present chief partner of the house of Dunbar, Dunbar, and Balderby, were in nowise astonished by this fact. They knew that, as a young man, Henry Dunbar had contracted the tastes and habits of an aristocrat, and that, if he had afterwards developed into a clever and successful man of business, it was only by reason of the force of circumstances, which had thrust him into a position that he hated.

column2: It was by no means wonderful, then, that, after becoming possessor of the united fortunes of his father and his uncle, Henry Dunbar should keep aloof from a place that had always been obnoxious to him.
column3: It was by no means wonderful, then, that, after becoming possessor of the united fortunes of his father and his uncle, Henry Dunbar should keep aloof from a place that had always been obnoxious to him.

column2: The business had gone on without him very well during his absence, and it went on without him now, for his place in India had been assumed by a very clever man, who for twenty years had acted as cashier in the Calcutta house.
column3: The business had gone on without him very well during his absence, and it went on without him now, for his place in India had been assumed by a very clever man, who for twenty years had acted as cashier in the Calcutta house.

column2: It may be that the banker had an unpleasant recollection of his last visit to St. Gundolph Lane, upon the day when the existence of the forged bills was discovered by Percival and Hugh Dunbar.
column3: It may be that the banker had an unpleasant recollection of his last visit to st Gundolph Lane, upon the day when the existence of the forged bills was discovered by Percival and Hugh Dunbar.

column2: All the width of thirty-five years between the present hour and that day might not be wide enough to separate the memory of the past from the thoughts which were busy this morning in the mind of Henry Dunbar.
column3: All the width of thirty five years between the present hour and that day might not be wide enough to separate the memory of the past from the thoughts which were busy this morning in the mind of Henry Dunbar.

column2: Be it as it might, Mr. Dunbar's reflections this day were evidently not of a pleasant nature.
column3: Be it as it might, mr Dunbar's reflections this day were evidently not of a pleasant nature.

column2: He was very pale as he rode citywards, in the comfortable brougham, from the Clarendon; and his face had a stern, fixed look, like a man who has nerved himself to meet some crisis, which he knows is near at hand.
column3: He was very pale as he rode citywards, in the comfortable brougham, from the Clarendon; and his face had a stern, fixed look, like a man who has nerved himself to meet some crisis, which he knows is near at hand.

column2: There was a stoppage upon Ludgate Hill.
column3: There was a stoppage upon Ludgate Hill.

column2: Great wooden barricades and mountains of uprooted paving-stones, amidst which sturdy navigators disported themselves with spades and pickaxes, and wheelbarrows full of rubbish, blocked the way; so the brougham turned into Farringdon Street, and went up Snow Hill, and under the grim black walls of dreadful Newgate.
column3: Great wooden barricades and mountains of uprooted paving stones, amidst which sturdy navigators disported themselves with spades and pickaxes, and wheelbarrows full of rubbish, blocked the way; so the brougham turned into Farringdon Street, and went up Snow Hill, and under the grim black walls of dreadful Newgate.

column2: The vehicle travelled very slowly, for the traffic was concentrated in this quarter by reason of the stoppage on Ludgate Hill, and Mr. Dunbar was able to contemplate at his leisure the black prison-walls, and the men and women selling dogs'-collars under their dismal shadows.
column3: The vehicle travelled very slowly, for the traffic was concentrated in this quarter by reason of the stoppage on Ludgate Hill, and mr Dunbar was able to contemplate at his leisure the black prison walls, and the men and women selling dogs'-collars under their dismal shadows.

column3: It may be that the banker's face grew a shade paler after that contemplation.

column2: The corners of his mouth twitched nervously as he got out of the carriage before the mahogany doors of the banking-house in St. Gundolph Lane.
column3: The corners of his mouth twitched nervously as he got out of the carriage before the mahogany doors of the banking house in st Gundolph Lane.

column2: But he drew a long breath, and held his head proudly erect as he pushed open the doors and went in.
column3: But he drew a long breath, and held his head proudly erect as he pushed open the doors and went in.

column2: Never since the day of the discovery of the forged bills had that man entered the banking-house.
column3: Never since the day of the discovery of the forged bills had that man entered the banking house.

column2: Dark thoughts came back upon his mind, and the shadows deepened on his face as he gave one rapid glance round the familiar office.
column3: Dark thoughts came back upon his mind, and the shadows deepened on his face as he gave one rapid glance round the familiar office.

column2: He walked straight towards the private parlour in which that well-remembered scene had occurred five-and-thirty years ago.
column3: He walked straight towards the private parlour in which that well remembered scene had occurred five and thirty years ago.

column2: But before he arrived at the door leading from the public offices to the back of the house, he was stopped by a gentlemanly-looking man, who came forward from a desk in some shadowy region, and intercepted the stranger.
column3: But before he arrived at the door leading from the public offices to the back of the house, he was stopped by a gentlemanly looking man, who came forward from a desk in some shadowy region, and intercepted the stranger.

column2: This man was Clement Austin, the cashier.
column3: This man was Clement Austin, the cashier.

column2: Do you wish to see Mr. Balderby, sir? he asked.
column3: Do you wish to see mr Balderby, sir? he asked.

column2: Yes.	Yes.
column3: true

column2: I have an appointment with him at one o'clock.
column3: I have an appointment with him at one o'clock.

column2: My name is Dunbar."
column3: My name is Dunbar."

column2: The cashier bowed and opened the door.
column3: The cashier bowed and opened the door.

column2: The banker passed across the threshold, which he had not crossed for five-and-thirty years until to-day.
column3: The banker passed across the threshold, which he had not crossed for five and thirty years until to day.

column2: But as Mr. Dunbar went towards the familiar parlour at the back of the banking-house, he stopped for a minute, and looked at the cashier.
column3: But as mr Dunbar went towards the familiar parlour at the back of the banking house, he stopped for a minute, and looked at the cashier.

column2: Clement Austin was scarcely less pale than Henry Dunbar himself.
column3: Clement Austin was scarcely less pale than Henry Dunbar himself.

column2: He had heard of the banker's intended visit to St. Gundolph Lane, and had looked forward with strange anxiety to a meeting with the man whom Margaret Wilmot declared to be the murderer of her father.
column3: He had heard of the banker's intended visit to st Gundolph Lane, and had looked forward with strange anxiety to a meeting with the man whom Margaret Wilmot declared to be the murderer of her father.

column2: Now that the meeting had come to pass, he looked at Henry Dunbar with an earnest, scrutinizing gaze, as if he would fain have discovered the secret of the man's guilt or innocence in his countenance.
column3: Now that the meeting had come to pass, he looked at Henry Dunbar with an earnest, scrutinizing gaze, as if he would fain have discovered the secret of the man's guilt or innocence in his countenance.

column2: The banker's face was pale, and grave, and stern; but Clement Austin knew that for Henry Dunbar there were very humiliating and unpleasant circumstances connected with the offices in St. Gundolph Lane, and it was scarcely to be expected that a man would come smiling into a place out of which he had gone five-and-thirty years before a disgraced and degraded creature.
column3: The banker's face was pale, and grave, and stern; but Clement Austin knew that for Henry Dunbar there were very humiliating and unpleasant circumstances connected with the offices in st Gundolph Lane, and it was scarcely to be expected that a man would come smiling into a place out of which he had gone five and thirty years before a disgraced and degraded creature.

column2: For a few moments the two men paused in the passage between the public offices and the private parlour, looking at each other.
column3: For a few moments the two men paused in the passage between the public offices and the private parlour, looking at each other.

column2: The banker's gaze never flinched during that encounter.
column3: The banker's gaze never flinched during that encounter.

column2: It is taken as a strong proof of a man's innocence that he should look you full in the face with a steadfast gaze when you look at him with suspicion plainly visible in your eyes; but would he not be the poorest villain if he shirked that encounter of glances when he knows full surely that he is in that moment put to the test?
column3: It is taken as a strong proof of a man's innocence that he should look you full in the face with a steadfast gaze when you look at him with suspicion plainly visible in your eyes; but would he not be the poorest villain if he shirked that encounter of glances when he knows full surely that he is in that moment put to the test?

column2: It is rather innocence whose eyelids drop when you peer too closely into its eyes, for innocence is appalled by the stern, accusing glances which it is unprepared to meet.
column3: It is rather innocence whose eyelids drop when you peer too closely into its eyes, for innocence is appalled by the stern, accusing glances which it is unprepared to meet.

column2: Guilt stares you boldly in the face, for guilt is hardened and defiant, and has this one grand superiority over innocence--that it is _prepared for the worst_.
column3: Guilt stares you boldly in the face, for guilt is hardened and defiant, and has this one grand superiority over innocence-that it is underscore prepared for the worst underscore.

column2: Clement Austin opened the door of Mr. Balderby's parlour; Mr. Dunbar went in unannounced.
column3: Clement Austin opened the door of mr Balderby's parlour; mr Dunbar went in unannounced.

column2: The cashier closed the parlour-door and returned to his desk in the public office.
column3: The cashier closed the parlour door and returned to his desk in the public office.

column2: The junior partner was sitting at an office table near the fire writing, but he rose as the banker entered the room, and went forward to meet him.
column3: The junior partner was sitting at an office table near the fire writing, but he rose as the banker entered the room, and went forward to meet him.

column2: You are very punctual, Mr. Dunbar, he said.
column3: You are very punctual, mr Dunbar, he said.

column2: Yes, I am generally punctual.
column3: Yes, I am generally punctual.

column2: The two men shook hands, and Mr. Balderby wheeled forward a morocco-covered arm-chair for his senior partner, and then took his seat opposite to him, with only the small office table between them.
column3: The two men shook hands, and mr Balderby wheeled forward a morocco covered arm chair for his senior partner, and then took his seat opposite to him, with only the small office table between them.

column2: It may seem late in the day to bid you welcome to the bank, Mr. Dunbar, said the junior partner, "but I do so, nevertheless--most heartily!"
column3: It may seem late in the day to bid you welcome to the bank, mr Dunbar, said the junior partner, "but I do so, nevertheless-most heartily!"

column2: There was a flatness in the accent in which these two last words were spoken, which was like the sound of a false coin when it falls dead upon a counter and proclaims itself spurious.
column3: There was a flatness in the accent in which these two last words were spoken, which was like the sound of a false coin when it falls dead upon a counter and proclaims itself spurious.

column2: Henry Dunbar did not return his partner's greeting.

column2: He was looking round the room, and remembering the day upon which he had last seen it.

column3: The morocco covered arm chairs had been re-covered, perhaps, during that five and thirty years; but if so, the covering had grown shabby again.

column2: Even the Turkey carpet was in the very stage of dusky dinginess that had distinguished the carpet on which Henry Dunbar had stood five-and-thirty years before.
column3: Even the Turkey carpet was in the very stage of dusky dinginess that had distinguished the carpet on which Henry Dunbar had stood five and thirty years before.

column2: I received your letter announcing your journey to London, and your desire for a private interview, on Saturday afternoon, Mr. Balderby said, after a pause.
column3: I received your letter announcing your journey to London, and your desire for a private interview, on Saturday afternoon, mr Balderby said, after a pause.

column2: I have made arrangements to assure our being undisturbed so long as you may remain here.	I have made arrangements to assure our being undisturbed so long as you may remain here.

column2: If you wish to make any investigation of the affairs of the house, I----"
column3: If you wish to make any investigation of the affairs of the house, I----"

column2: Mr. Dunbar waved his hand with a deprecatory air.

column2: Nothing is farther from my thoughts than any such design, he said. "No, Mr. Balderby, I have only been a man of business because all chance of another career, which I infinitely preferred, was closed upon me five-and-thirty years ago.
column3: Nothing is farther from my thoughts than any such design, he said. "No, mr Balderby, I have only been a man of business because all chance of another career, which I infinitely preferred, was closed upon me five and thirty years ago.

column2: I am quite content to be a sleeping-partner in the house of Dunbar, Dunbar, and Balderby.
column3: I am quite content to be a sleeping partner in the house of Dunbar, Dunbar, and Balderby.

column2: For ten years prior to my father's death he took no active part in the business.
column3: For ten years prior to my father's death he took no active part in the business.

column2: The house got on very well without his aid; it will get on equally well without mine.
column3: The house got on very well without his aid; it will get on equally well without mine.

column2: The business that brings me to London is an entirely personal matter.
column3: The business that brings me to London is an entirely personal matter.

column2: I am a rich man, but I don't exactly know how rich I am, and I want to realize rather a large sum of money."
column3: I am a rich man, but I don't exactly know how rich I am, and I want to realize rather a large sum of money."

column2: Mr. Balderby bowed, but his eyebrows went up a little, as if he found it impossible to control some slight evidence of his surprise.
column3: mr Balderby bowed, but his eyebrows went up a little, as if he found it impossible to control some slight evidence of his surprise.

column2: Previous to my daughter's marriage I settled upon her the house in Portland Place and the Yorkshire property.	Previous to my daughter's marriage I settled upon her the house in Portland Place and the Yorkshire property.

column2: She will have all my money when I die; and, as Sir Philip Jocelyn is a rich man, she will perhaps be one of the wealthiest women in England.
column3: She will have all my money when I die; and, as Sir Philip Jocelyn is a rich man, she will perhaps be one of the wealthiest women in England.

column2: So far so good.
column3: So far so good.

column2: Neither Laura nor her husband will have any reason for dissatisfaction.
column3: Neither Laura nor her husband will have any reason for dissatisfaction.

column2: But this is not quite enough, Mr. Balderby.
column3: But this is not quite enough, mr Balderby.

column2: I am not a demonstrative man, and I have never made any great fuss about my love for my daughter; but I do love her, nevertheless."
column3: I am not a demonstrative man, and I have never made any great fuss about my love for my daughter; but I do love her, nevertheless."

column3: We Anglo Indians have rather a magnificent way of doing things, mr Balderby he continued, "when we take it into our heads to do them at all.

column2: I want to give my daughter a diamond-necklace as a wedding present, and I want it to be such as an Eastern prince or a Rothschild might offer to his only child.

column2: You understand?"
column3: You understand?"

column2: Oh, perfectly, answered Mr. Balderby; "I shall be most happy to be of any use to you in the matter."

column2: All I want is a large sum of money at my command.	All I want is a large sum of money at my command.

column2: You and John Lovell, of Shorncliffe, were the executors to my father's will.

column2: You signed an order for the transfer of my father's money to my account some time in last September."

column2: I did, in concurrence with Mr. Lovell.
column3: I did, in concurrence with mr Lovell.

column2: My father kept two accounts here, I believe--a deposit and a drawing account?"
column3: My father kept two accounts here, I believe-a deposit and a drawing account?"

column2: He did.
column3: He did.

column2: And those two accounts have gone on since my return in the same manner as during his lifetime?
column3: And those two accounts have gone on since my return in the same manner as during his lifetime?

column3: Perhaps you can let me see the ledgers containing those two accounts?

column2: How is this money invested? asked Henry Dunbar, pointing to the page. His fingers trembled a little as he did so, and he dropped his hand suddenly upon the ledger.

column3: There's fifty thousand in India stock, mr Balderby answered, as indifferently as if fifty thousand pounds more or less was scarcely worth speaking of; "and there's five and twenty in railway debentures, Great Western.

column3: Most of the remainder is floating in Exchequer bills."

column2: Our calls are sometimes heavy.

column2: Certainly, Mr. Dunbar.
column3: Certainly, mr Dunbar.

column2: Then I think that is really all I have to say.	Then I think that is really all I have to say.
column3: true

column2: I shall be happy to see you at the Clarendon, if you will dine with me any evening that you are disengaged."
column3: I shall be happy to see you at the Clarendon, if you will dine with me any evening that you are disengaged."

column2: There was very little heartiness in the tone of this invitation; and Mr. Balderby perfectly understood that it was only a formula which Mr. Dunbar felt himself called upon to go through.
column3: There was very little heartiness in the tone of this invitation; and mr Balderby perfectly understood that it was only a formula which mr Dunbar felt himself called upon to go through.

column2: The junior partner murmured his acknowledgment of Henry Dunbar's politeness; and then the two men talked together for a few minutes on indifferent subjects.
column3: The junior partner murmured his acknowledgment of Henry Dunbar's politeness; and then the two men talked together for a few minutes on indifferent subjects.

column2: Five minutes afterwards Mr. Dunbar rose to leave the room.
column3: Five minutes afterwards mr Dunbar rose to leave the room.

column2: He went into the passage between Mr. Balderby's parlour and the public offices of the bank.
column3: He went into the passage between mr Balderby's parlour and the public offices of the bank.

column2: This passage was very dark; but the offices were well lighted by lofty plate-glass windows.
column3: This passage was very dark; but the offices were well lighted by lofty plate glass windows.

column2: Between the end of the passage and the outer doors of the bank, Henry Dunbar saw the figure of a woman sitting near one of the desks and talking to Clement Austin.
column3: Between the end of the passage and the outer doors of the bank, Henry Dunbar saw the figure of a woman sitting near one of the desks and talking to Clement Austin.

column2: The banker stopped suddenly, and went back to the parlour.
column3: The banker stopped suddenly, and went back to the parlour.

column2: He looked about him a little absently as he re-entered the room.
column3: He looked about him a little absently as he re-entered the room.

column2: I thought I brought a cane, he said.
column3: I thought I brought a cane, he said.

column2: I think not, replied Mr. Balderby, rising from before his desk.
column3: I think not, replied mr Balderby, rising from before his desk.

column2: I don't remember seeing one in your hand.
column3: I don't remember seeing one in your hand.

column2: Ah, then, I suppose I was mistaken.
column3: Ah, then, I suppose I was mistaken.

column2: He still lingered in the parlour, putting on his gloves very slowly, and looking out of the window into the dismal backyard, where there was a dingy little wooden door set deep in the stone wall.
column3: He still lingered in the parlour, putting on his gloves very slowly, and looking out of the window into the dismal backyard, where there was a dingy little wooden door set deep in the stone wall.

column2: While the banker loitered near the window, Clement Austin came into the room, to show some document to the junior partner.
column3: While the banker loitered near the window, Clement Austin came into the room, to show some document to the junior partner.

column2: Henry Dunbar turned round as the cashier was about to leave the parlour.
column3: Henry Dunbar turned round as the cashier was about to leave the parlour.

column2: I saw a woman just now talking to you in the office.	I saw a woman just now talking to you in the office.
column3: false

column2: That's not very business-like, is it, Mr. Austin?
column3: That's not very business like, is it, mr Austin?

column2: Who is the woman?"
column3: Who is the woman?"

column2: She is a young lady, sir.
column3: She is a young lady, sir.

column2: A young lady?
column3: A young lady?

column2: Yes, sir.
column3: Yes, sir.

column2: What brings her here?
column3: What brings her here?

column2: The cashier hesitated for a moment before he replied, "She--wishes to see you, Mr. Dunbar," he said, after that brief pause.
column3: The cashier hesitated for a moment before he replied, "She-wishes to see you, mr Dunbar," he said, after that brief pause.

column2: What is her name?--who--who is she?
column3: What is her name?--who-who is she?

column2: Her name is Wilmot--Margaret Wilmot.
column3: Her name is Wilmot-Margaret Wilmot.

column2: I know no such person! answered the banker, haughtily, but looking nervously at the half-opened door as he spoke.
column3: I know no such person! answered the banker, haughtily, but looking nervously at the half opened door as he spoke.

column2: Shut that door, sir! he said, impatiently, to the cashier; "the draught from the passage is strong enough to cut a man in two.
column3: Shut that door, sir! he said, impatiently, to the cashier; "the draught from the passage is strong enough to cut a man in two.

column2: Who is this Margaret Wilmot?"
column3: Who is this Margaret Wilmot?"

column2: The daughter of that unfortunate man, Joseph Wilmot, who was cruelly murdered at Winchester! answered the cashier, very gravely.
column3: The daughter of that unfortunate man, Joseph Wilmot, who was cruelly murdered at Winchester! answered the cashier, very gravely.

column2: He looked Henry Dunbar full in the face as he spoke.
column3: He looked Henry Dunbar full in the face as he spoke.

column2: The banker returned his look as unflinchingly as he had done before, and spoke in a hard, unfaltering voice as he answered: "Tell this person, Margaret Wilmot, that I refuse to see her to-day, as I refused to see her in Portland Place, and as I refused to see her at Winchester!" he said, deliberately.
column3: The banker returned his look as unflinchingly as he had done before, and spoke in a hard, unfaltering voice as he answered: "Tell this person, Margaret Wilmot, that I refuse to see her to day, as I refused to see her in Portland Place, and as I refused to see her at Winchester!" he said, deliberately.

column2: Tell her that I shall always refuse to see her, whenever or wherever she makes an attack upon me.	Tell her that I shall always refuse to see her, whenever or wherever she makes an attack upon me.
column3: false

column2: I have suffered enough already on account of that hideous business at Winchester, and I shall most resolutely defend myself from any further persecution.
column3: I have suffered enough already on account of that hideous business at Winchester, and I shall most resolutely defend myself from any further persecution.

column2: This young person can have no possible motive for wishing to see me.
column3: This young person can have no possible motive for wishing to see me.

column2: If she is poor and wants money of me, I am ready and willing to assist her.
column3: If she is poor and wants money of me, I am ready and willing to assist her.

column2: I have already offered to do so--I can do no more.
column3: I have already offered to do so-I can do no more.

column2: But if she is in distress----"
column3: But if she is in distress----"

column2: She is not in distress, Mr. Dunbar, interrupted Clement Austin.
column3: She is not in distress, mr Dunbar, interrupted Clement Austin.

column2: She has friends who love her well enough to shield her from that.
column3: She has friends who love her well enough to shield her from that.

column2: Indeed; and you are one of those friends, I suppose, Mr. Austin?
column3: Indeed; and you are one of those friends, I suppose, mr Austin?

column2: I am.
column3: I am.

column2: Prove your friendship, then, by teaching Margaret Wilmot that she has a friend and not an enemy in me.	Prove your friendship, then, by teaching Margaret Wilmot that she has a friend and not an enemy in me.
column3: true

column2: If you are--as I suspect from your manner--something more than a friend: if you love her, and she returns your love, marry her, and she shall have a dowry that no gentleman's wife need be ashamed to bring to her husband."
column3: If you are-as I suspect from your manner-something more than a friend: if you love her, and she returns your love, marry her, and she shall have a dowry that no gentleman's wife need be ashamed to bring to her husband."

column2: There was no anger, no impatience in the banker's voice now, but a tone of deep feeling.
column3: There was no anger, no impatience in the banker's voice now, but a tone of deep feeling.

column2: Clement Austin locked at him, astonished by the change in his manner.
column3: Clement Austin locked at him, astonished by the change in his manner.

column2: Henry Dunbar saw the look, and it seemed as if he endeavoured to answer it.
column3: Henry Dunbar saw the look, and it seemed as if he endeavoured to answer it.

column2: You have no need to be surprised that I shrink from seeing Margaret Wilmot, he said.
column3: You have no need to be surprised that I shrink from seeing Margaret Wilmot, he said.

column2: Cannot you understand that my nerves may be none of the strongest, and that I cannot endure the idea of an interview with this girl, who, no doubt, by her persistent pursuit of me, suspects me of her father's murder?	Cannot you understand that my nerves may be none of the strongest, and that I cannot endure the idea of an interview with this girl, who, no doubt, by her persistent pursuit of me, suspects me of her father's murder?
column3: false

column2: I am an old man, and I have been thirty-five years in India.
column3: I am an old man, and I have been thirty five years in India.

column2: My health is shattered, and I have a horror of all tragic scenes.
column3: My health is shattered, and I have a horror of all tragic scenes.

column2: I have not yet recovered from the shock of that horrible business at Winchester.
column3: I have not yet recovered from the shock of that horrible business at Winchester.

column2: Go and tell Margaret Wilmot this: tell her that I will be her true friend if she will accept that friendship, but that I will not see her until she has learned to think better of me."
column3: Go and tell Margaret Wilmot this: tell her that I will be her true friend if she will accept that friendship, but that I will not see her until she has learned to think better of me."

column2: There was something very straightforward, very simple, in all this.
column3: There was something very straightforward, very simple, in all this.

column2: For a time, at least, Clement Austin's mind wavered.
column3: For a time, at least, Clement Austin's mind wavered.

column2: Margaret was, perhaps, wrong, after all, and Henry Dunbar might be an innocent man.
column3: Margaret was, perhaps, wrong, after all, and Henry Dunbar might be an innocent man.

column2: It was Clement who had informed Margaret of Mr. Dunbar's expected presence here upon this day; and it was on the strength of that information that the girl had come to St. Gundolph Lane, with the determination of seeing the man whom she believed to be the murderer of her father.
column3: It was Clement who had informed Margaret of mr Dunbar's expected presence here upon this day; and it was on the strength of that information that the girl had come to st Gundolph Lane, with the determination of seeing the man whom she believed to be the murderer of her father.

column2: Clement returned to the office, where he had left Margaret, in order to repeat to her Mr. Dunbar's message.
column3: Clement returned to the office, where he had left Margaret, in order to repeat to her mr Dunbar's message.

column2: No sooner had the door of the parlour closed upon the cashier than Henry Dunbar turned abruptly to his junior partner.
column3: No sooner had the door of the parlour closed upon the cashier than Henry Dunbar turned abruptly to his junior partner.

column2: There is a door leading from the yard into a court that connects St. Gundolph Lane with another lane at the back, he said, "is there not?"
column3: There is a door leading from the yard into a court that connects st Gundolph Lane with another lane at the back, he said, "is there not?"

column2: He pointed to the dark little yard outside the window as he spoke.
column3: He pointed to the dark little yard outside the window as he spoke.

column2: Yes, there is a door, I believe.
column3: Yes, there is a door, I believe.

column2: Is it locked?
column3: Is it locked?

column2: No; it is seldom locked till four o'clock; the clerks use it sometimes, when they go in and out.
column3: No; it is seldom locked till four o'clock; the clerks use it sometimes, when they go in and out.

column2: Then I shall go out that way, said Mr. Dunbar, who was almost breathless in his haste.
column3: Then I shall go out that way, said mr Dunbar, who was almost breathless in his haste.

column2: You can send the carriage back to the Clarendon by-and-by.	You can send the carriage back to the Clarendon by and by.

column2: I don't want to see that girl.
column3: I don't want to see that girl.

column2: Good morning."
column3: Good morning."

column2: He hurried out of the parlour, and into a passage leading to the yard, followed by Mr. Balderby, who wondered at his senior partner's excitement.
column3: He hurried out of the parlour, and into a passage leading to the yard, followed by mr Balderby, who wondered at his senior partner's excitement.

column2: The door in the yard was not locked.
column3: The door in the yard was not locked.

column2: Henry Dunbar opened it, went out into the court, and closed the door behind him.
column3: Henry Dunbar opened it, went out into the court, and closed the door behind him.

column2: So, for the third time, he escaped from an interview with Margaret Wilmot.
column3: So, for the third time, he escaped from an interview with Margaret Wilmot.

column2: CHAPTER XXVII.
column3: CHAPTER twenty seven.

column2: CLEMENT AUSTIN'S WOOING.
column3: CLEMENT AUSTIN'S WOOING.

column2: For the third time Margaret Wilmot was disappointed in the hope of seeing Henry Dunbar.
column3: For the third time Margaret Wilmot was disappointed in the hope of seeing Henry Dunbar.

column2: Clement Austin had on the previous evening told her of the banker's intended visit to the office in St. Gundolph Lane, and the young music-mistress had made hasty arrangements for the postponement of her usual duties, in order that she might go to the City to see Henry Dunbar.
column3: Clement Austin had on the previous evening told her of the banker's intended visit to the office in st Gundolph Lane, and the young music mistress had made hasty arrangements for the postponement of her usual duties, in order that she might go to the City to see Henry Dunbar.
